Comment: Debra Son says "research suggests that men who are exposed to lower levels of prenatal androgens are more likely to be female-typical in their behaviour and sexually attracted to men". However, the paper she cites actually refers to rats and ferrets, not men. Not mentioning that is not good science. Also, in addition to genetic forces, there are undoubtedly cultural influences to many gender-related activities (for example, it is doubtful that the propensity to shave one's legs is genetically determined). It is therefore likely as wrong to attribute all gender differences to acculturation as it is to attribute them all to genetics. Either way, it is important to appreciate and respect the diversity of human expressions, and to avoid stereotyping.

Comment: "This is just a tidbit, but it's an interesting one. Here's the background: Legalized marijuana, which is pretty obviously gaining ground steadily, leads to higher marijuana use (duh) and thus to higher rates of driving while stoned. Or does it? The problem is that THC remains in your system for a week or more after you've smoked a joint, so even if you test positive at a roadside stop it doesn't necessarily mean that you're stoned now—or even that you've smoked within the past day, let alone the past few hours. As a result, drivers who are perfectly safe run the risk of being unfairly convicted of impaired driving, while drivers who are stoned can often escape conviction if they have a good lawyer." from Mother Jones....

 The testing has "caught up" with the issue and there are now tests which will detect "recent" use of marijuana...i.e. is the person impaired because of marijuana use.  This provideds a sensible context for Sen. Prozanski's bill...Gary Crum

Comment: Grenfield tower is yet another example of the great divide between rich and poor, and the power and arrogance of global companies. 
This cladding was known to be unsafe, yet some company has marketed it and sold it to dozens, perhaps hundreds, of hotels, developers and councils around Britain for use in multistory buildings for which it was demonstrably unsafe. 
Over a hundred years ago two of my forebears were caught in the Stanley pit disaster of 1909 where 168 men lost their lives. It was caused by a large Davey lamp that was approx 2ft wide. Lamps over 1ft wide were known to be unsafe yet the company continued to use them until the explosion occurred. My g-g uncle and his son aged 14 were both killed in the Tilley seam and another g-uncle lost his leg in the rescue attempt. Two weeks later my g-gmother was evicted from her house with the rest of the children because she no longer had a husband working in the mine. 
Things haven't changed.

Comment: What you are forgetting is that the money paid to state employees through those 98% of programs circulates throughout the economy and keeps Alaskan businesses open. Without that money to prop up the Alaskan economy there would literally be little left worth saving. The permanent fund will have disappeared...it will anyway just as soon as the budget reserve evaporates in another year of dawdling around. Those few people left in Alaska will be paying income taxes and sales taxes through the nose to pay for what little is left of the state's essential services: police, fire, education, road maintenance and things like running the DMV. But go ahead and wish away the real problems that come to all states dependent upon a single revenue source when that revenue source is rapidly declining. There are finite limits to other revenue sources. (1) corporate income taxes, (2) individual income taxes, (3) property taxes, and (4) sales taxes. None of them is popular, but that's the available menu.

Comment: That's not really how it works. Wasilla and Palmer are municipal police and convention limits them to areas that pay for their services, i.e. City limits. Wasilla and Palmer taxpayers don't want to pay to patrol areas that aren't paying for the service and then not have a cop available because he's off in trooperland.

The borough could form a new police entity, but only few borough forces exist in the state (North Slope being one). It would be expensive and time consuming, not to mention a logistical headache with the borough contracts outstanding. AST would also likely diminish its own patrols as borough police stood up more.

I think a borough force is a good idea, but don't expect it to be making a huge dent in crime for at least a year or two.

Comment: I found this Backgrounder for Parliamentarians written in 2004. I am sure the essence of today's dispute was as before. Lumber companies bid for tracts of land to harvest and an auction thereby establishing the 'market price' to be paid to the private landowner. In Canada, Atlantic Canada excluded, the Crown owns the land and sets the 'stumpage fee' that a company must pay in order to harvest. The U.S. feels stumpage rates are below the 'market price' used in the U.S. thereby conferring an unfair advantage to Canadian companies.

I'll just throw an idea out here. Why can't Canadian stumpage fees track the U.S. 'market price' the way that ETF's or mutual funds track a market index? I suppose Provincial Governments need revenue certainty, but surely there must be a way. Otherwise we continue on as we have with no resolution in sight.

http://www.lop.parl.gc.ca/content/lop/ResearchPublications/tips/tip98-e.htm

Comment: Kids are competitive - it is in their nature.  In kindergarten is you leave them along in the playground they will race each other across the schoolyard. We should embrace it, not suppress it.

Comment: There are actually terms for Trump's behavior.  His need for adoration, being looked at, literally, as in the expression on people's faces, and talked about in glowingly parallel terms in speech or in writing.  It is called "narcissistic supply," and it is what narcissists live for above all else.  When they don't get it and they react vindictively, as Trump routinely does, it is called "narcissistic injury."   

His lack of a core center that contains an authentic self is what drives the continuous changes in his views, because he "mirrors" others, pretty much whoever he last spoke with that provided the necessary "narcissistic supply."    

Had the DSM not eliminated the diagnosis of narcissistic personality disorder from the cluster Bs, I'd bet a lot of money that Trump would be the poster child for NPD.  But the APA included NPD in the criteria for anti-social personality disorder recently, which identifies them "sociopaths."

Comment: In both cases two things hold:

- the day of the feast begins at sundown

- the evening of the feast concludes what had been, and still is among the Orthodox, rigorous fasts. The sooner the feast begins, the sooner the fast ends

- the ceilings of sanctuaries of traditional Catholic churches are decorated to resemble the heavens since the Mass is the heavenly sacrifice offered perpetually to the Father

- the domes of Orthodox and eastern sanctuaries are decorated with angels and the icon of Christ the Pantokrator for the same reason

Well folks, it couldn't possibly be more straightforward: Trump believes he is a master negotiator and deal-maker, and his brilliant, fool-proof strategy is tough talk and asking for more than he really wants at the outset. 

The media can't help but respond to Trump's about faces, inconsistencies and provocations - that's their job - but it is beginning to dawn on leaders and much of the public as well that Trump's bag of tricks is incredibly limited and simple-minded. Amazingly, his voting base is still impressed with his swaggering tough guy act, but everyone else is cluing in to how vapid and predictable Trump is.

Comment: Charles:  Those family wage jobs were lost to outsourcing and, for those which remained (and remain in our country) to the never-ending quest for "productivity." Productivity is the measure of output per work hour, and you increase it, primarily, by having fewer workers.  You accomplish that with the matching ever-increasing automation of production.  A "faller-buncher" can, in a day, do a weeks work of a logging crew.  A highly automated mill can produce far more lumber with far fewer workers than was ever the case with previous mills. Comment: A few years ago I worked with the then Director for Center for Alaska Coastal Studies on preserving the 2 beaches near their field station for tide pooling activities for the school children of Alaska. It was in response to the increase in clamming activities in the area. New visitors in the area not being familiar would dig for clams on these beaches not being aware that this was not an abundant area for clams and the beaches were being hit heavily because they were accessible by small boats.  I worked for almost 2 years gathering all the information and support to make a case to the Alaska Department of Fish and Game why the beaches needed to be protected.  The information was submitted and the next step was to attend the Board of Fisheries and then I went to the meeting and spoke my 5 minutes in support. I was indeed a "curiosity" since no one had ever proposed that in this state before. 3 days later the Board of Fisheries approved the measure and it was a now a state law.

Comment: It would actually have helped for you to elaborate.  Those other states are similarly underpopulated and therefore considered to be an unattractive market for insurers.  I can't speak specifically to the other states, but there has been a constant struggle in Alaska to find insurers willing to provide taxi insurance to this market.  Taxis in Fairbanks went from charging $1/mile to over $3/mile in a relatively short span, which is directly attributable to the constant rise of insurance premiums.  When Uber finally gets established and folks realize that their personal insurance without commercial endorsements just won't cut it, I have to wonder if they will be similarly taken to the cleaners by the insurance companies.

Comment: CSPAN has the video if you want to watch it.  

During a 1992 Senate floor speech, Joe Biden said President George H. W. Bush should wait to fill any Supreme Court vacancies until after the presidential election. 

“It is my view that if a Supreme Court Justice resigns tomorrow or within the next several weeks or resigns at the end of the summer, President Bush should consider following the practice of a majority of his predecessors and not, and not name a nominee until after the November election is completed,” Biden said at the time. Biden went onto say that delaying a Supreme Court nomination until after the election is what is fair to the nominee and essential to the process.

The floor comments were made on June 25, months before the 1992 presidential election.

Comment: Are hospitals able to choose their mandate in terms of service delivery ? For example, can a hospital decide they won't provide pre-natal care, or palliative care, or perform certain reasonably common procedures.

But presumably if they are mandated to provide certain services and this procedure falls under palliative care, then they would be required to provide it.

I think individual doctors should have conscience exceptions but the hospital as an institution has no such protection, and should be required to bring in individuals to perform the procedure if it is required.

Also, hospitals remove feeding tubes and turn off ventilators - how is that not assisted dying ?

Comment: * Hilcorp Alaska was fined $100,000 by the federal agency to settle violations by that company, the EPA said.
* Hilcorp in February 2015 spilled nearly 10,000 gallons of crude oil and produced water from a leak in the bottom of a pipeline at the Milne Point field. The spill affected 40,000 square feet of Arctic tundra and gravel pad, the agency said. The spill was initially reported as 4,000 gallons, and occurred from a relatively new pipeline.
* A stubborn fire on a Cook Inlet natural gas platform near Nikiski on Thursday morning triggered the evacuation
* Firefighting vessels continued spraying water at the Hilcorp Alaska LLC platform into early afternoon
* Hilcorp has paid a $115,500 civil penalty for the latest in a string of enforcement actions drilling regulators have taken against the company during its brief time as an oil and gas operator in Alaska.

Comment: As far as I know all 4 of the existing rest stops are in her ward. They're run by Community Supported Shelters, which has periodic tours of the one on the north side of Roosevelt near Garfield. Two more of their rest stops are in the triangle formed by the railroad tracks, Chambers & NW Expressway.  The fourth, for veterans, is on the Mission grounds. http://communitysupportedshelters.org/

Nightingale Health Sanctuary ran 2 more rest stops side by side at a county location off of MLK Jr. For some reason they had to move to the Mission, which would only host one. Then, because of pressure from the Whiteaker neighborhood, the City Council and Manager kicked NHS out of the Mission grounds, even though the Mission was willing to keep it, and put only 6 of its residents into a "car camp" in south Eugene. NHS runs that camp, but it's not a rest stop, which can have up to 20 residents.

The City Council has passed the buck to the neighborhood associations, which have produced no new sites.

Comment: The Constitution does not require a separation of church and state, notwithstanding what Thomas Jefferson wrote about it.  Jefferson had no part in writing the Constitution; he was in France even when the Constitutional Convention was held.

Nowhere does it say that the government or its members must be secular.  

The Bill of Rights is a restriction on Federal government power over the People.  The First Amendment prohibits the government from imposing a government religion on the People, from making laws about the practice of religion, and from restricting people on practicing their religion.  

The Federal Government through its officials can espouse, e.g., a belief in God, a belief in transubstantiation, a belief that Jesus is the savior, and that Joseph Smith was a heretic.  As long as it does not mandate those beliefs on the People, it is Constitutional to do that.

Comment: Greenhouses for local subsistence are not a new idea in arctic Alaska; however those which were in use many decades ago fell out of favor for a variety of reasons. 

Published accounts, some even with pictures from those olden days, were still in existence before 1970; some date from the 1920s or before. Some most successful in the 1940s through '60s. However vegetables don't imply a great deal of comfort, and once the village stores began stocking sweet and fatty foods, the local greenhouses faded away.

The lack of Alaska history (at least from the Russian era or before, forward) being taught in the schools along with a pre-history of how people adapted to the far north through intelligent use of local resources, may lead to a better understanding of how life has changed in those areas; now 'accelerated climate change' is really a game changer. The people who moved there between major ice-ages were very bright... and the light has not grown dim over the millennia of time passage.

Comment: I suspect that the "wage gap" is primarily a creation of comparing non-identical work. Double blind studies are often utilized in order to eliminate bias in those who perform the study.  It creeps in in many ways.

Comment: $60K a year will barely get you an apartment in Portland and an occasional  box of Voodoo Donuts. After taxes you might be taking home $3,500 a month, if you are single. You will spend close to half of that to live in a "comfortable" apartment and you can FORGET about buying a home!

Another $500 for health insurance and you are down to perhaps a $1,000-$1,2000 a month in take-home pay. Try living comfortably on that kind of money and get back to me.

As Thomas Frank pointed out in the pages of this very newspaper less than a month ago, Portland is a city that has been built for winners, as in "winners" of the economic game and making $60,000 a year is NOT winning the economic game! 

In fact it is barely 10% more than the median household income in the United States, which means that you are almost as likely to earn that kind of money in Topeka, KS or Jacksonville, FL as you are in Portland...in other words in cities where you really CAN live "comfortably" on $60,000 a year!

Comment: This was not a murder conviction as understood anywhere except the bizarre and twisted US military commission tribunal in Guantanamo.

It was years later the US invented a crime that did not exist heretofore and exists nowhere else in civil criminal, military or international law . We have laws prohibiting convictions 'ex post facto' crimes - see the Charter at S. 11(g) as does the US (clause 3 of Article I, Section 9 of the US Constitution) and it is the basis under which a number of Gitmo convictions have already been overturned. Khadr's appeal has yet to be heard as the US is using every preocedural delay.

After the Military Commissions Act of 2006 was signed in October 2006, new charges were sworn against Khadr on February 2, 2007. He was charged with Murder in Violation of the Law of War - a wholly US invented crime that did not exist before 2006 and is not recognized anywhere else in the world. A clear violation of the prohibition on 'ex post facto' crimes.

Comment: Federal law requires the states to report the popular vote numbers in a "Certificate of Ascertainment." Those counts determine each state's electoral votes.

No statewide recount, much less a nationwide recount, would have been warranted in any of the nation’s 58  presidential elections if the outcome had been based on the  nationwide count. 

The state-by-state winner-take-all system is not a firewall, but instead causes unnecessary fires.
“It’s an arsonist itching to burn down the whole neighborhood by torching a single house.” Hertzberg

The 2000 presidential election was an artificial crisis created because of Bush's lead of 537 popular votes in Florida. Gore's nationwide lead was 537,179 popular votes (1,000 times larger). Given the minuscule number of votes that are changed by a typical statewide recount (averaging only 274 votes); no one would have requested a recount or disputed the results in 2000 if the national popular vote had controlled the outcome.

What is harmful is angry reactionary anti-everything demagoguery that tries to pass itself as being within the democratic conservative tradition and the upsurge of this in the form of free market nihilism ( think O'Leary), reactionary social conservatism (think Leitch) and free form demagoguery (think Doug Ford) now threatens the long-term viability of the Conservative Party.

Manning could credibly oppose such unsavory populist extremism but he is under the illusion that he and other 'wise leaders' can somehow channel this extremism to constructive ends.  

This hubris does him no credit and the  Conservative Party are at risk in the absence of the distinct between conservative and reactionary politics being strongly drawn.

Comment: As indicated in the July 2016 Canada's Ecofiscal Commission report, "Comparing Stringency of Carbon Pricing Policies", more stringent policies on the level of GHG emissions-reduction and the price of carbon are needed at the provincial and federal level. Coordinating provincial carbon pricing policies will help ensure that low-cost emissions reductions across the country are realized, while high-cost abatement is avoided.
"The stringency of a carbon pricing policy is its ability to drive reductions in GHG emissions. A carbon pricing policy does not automatically reduce emissions, success depends on the policy's stringency. More stringent policy is clearly required to achieve Canada's stated emissions-reduction target for 2030 -  30% below 2005 levels. But to what extent will individual provinces contribute toward the overall national effort?"
Unless provincial and federal politicians keep their political agenda aside and work together, Canada won't be able to reach its 2030 target.

Comment: We're all different. We need to check our CPP earnings projection (available online). These are mine. I'm retired at 61. If I start collecting now I get about $8,000 per year CPP. That rises to >$11,300 if I wait to 65 and more than doubles to >$16,000 if I wait to age 70. If I wait four years to 65, I need to take $32,000 (4 x $8,000) out of my investment accounts to spend the same as if I opted to collect CPP now. By waiting to 65, I get a CPP that's $3,300 more per year, PLUS the inflation adjustment each following year that is based on a larger base. For financial purposes I plan to live to 94 (then sell the house). In my case, CPP at 65 actually puts less strain on my investment accounts. They would run out at age 91 if I collected now but if I wait to 65 I'd still have a cushion left at age 94 — spending the same amount. How's that possible? Because 29 years of collecting $3,300 more ($89,100) will probably leave more in my wallet than saving $32,000 now. Run your own numbers.

Comment: The Regent's argument is fundamentally flawed. They only have a limited grant of authority, a single line in their Charter in fact, to set regulations for the "good order" of the system, nothing approaching the authority to utterly abrogate a fundamental right.
Further they deliberately ignore the multiple states and dozens of campuses with years of experience with campus carry who report none of their "concerns" as actual problems in reality.
Further, they are playing fast and loose with Reason. Their current policy has zero legal weight, there is no legal sanction and thus no deterrant value. If someone is found to be carrying all campus staff and police is ask them to leave. If they refuse they can be trespassed. If a student or staff, academic and admin sanctions may occur. There is no reasonable way to claim this policy deters nor physically can -prevent-  someone intending to commit violence from violating a violent crime. It can only deter the law-abiding who aren't threats.

Comment: Canai,
This is why I liked the program in NM. They realized that the majority of people being repeatedly admitted to the hospital were also the same folks who used the ER on a repeated basis. Most had mental health conditions with medical issues, many were from the homeless population, either had a substance abuse problem or mental health problem. Once identified,they were encouraged to be part of the program where a nurse practioner does home visits on a daily or weekly basis. The program does a lot of advocacy, problem solving, from helping homeless to find housing, get regular meals, insure they get their medication, to any other need that they have that affects their health. If they find that the person is a veteran, they help them get hooked in with using VA services and benifits. With this program, a decrease in hospitalization, a big decrease in the "frequent flyers" at the ER with over all improvement in health for the patient has occurred and a saving in time and resources.

Comment: This wasn't mainly about fire sprinklers.  It was about problems with the building.  We will find out that the fire department had a problem getting up to the fire.   Elevators weren't working so HFD had to walk up to the fire which allowed the fire to burn hotter and spread.  The fire alarm system wasn't up to code so residents didn't hear them clearly.   The doors to the units weren't fire preventive doors (they allowed air to easily flow in and out, allowing the fire to spread easily) so they burned quickly and the fire crossed the hallway.   When the facts come out we will find that this fire was bad and could have been prevented or controlled with less costly fixes.  People should not have died if things were done properly.

Comment: Texting and Driving is a major issue. It is a technological problem that does have a technological solution. There are a number of apps, many of them FREE that can block texts, redirect phone calls to voice mail, and impede other apps. One is AT&T DriveMode. 'Another issue is fleet vehicles/company cars. People who are driving as part of their work often think they can return calls, catch up on emails and texts while they drive. Those "on the clock" drive more than leisure drivers, during peak traffic, and when other distracted drivers are on the road. You can use tech to block phone use when driving. How great if Washington lead by example and put the tech in all their government vehicles: inspectors, regulators, and agriculture.

Comment: The remaining line through the city has to be at-grade.  Just move the bike lane on King Street to a less invasive street like Young, and put the tracks in the current bike lane.  (Or rail could offer free rides to bikers on King.)  Yes, it will still take up space on King, but at least you can SEE the train coming as opposed to little bikes, and the lane is already taken at the moment.  Plus, if it is on King Street, then the rail is taking people directly into the heart of the city meaning fewer or no buses needed, and you won't have to build any huge hulking rail stations.  Just put stops along the street.  The rail would still have to follow street lights, but with it's own dedicated lane, there should be no traffic back up.  That way, you might even have extra money (What am I thinking?) to make it at-grade all the way to UH (King-University intersection).  I'm not and never have been a fan of rail, but if we're going to do this anyway, then make it as cost effective as possible!

Comment: After a late winter cruise, it was time to lose some weight. I decided on a calorie/weight scale based diet. I determined that my break even is 2,500 calories a day, add on for exercise. The diet is eat and drink whatever I want to a maximum of 1,500 calories a day. One day a week is off the diet allowing 2,200-3,000 calories for that day. Getting on the scale once a day is mandatory. So is recording every bite of food and drink, no lying.
So far, I have lost 25 pounds in 8 weeks. I have had great food, changed my diet to accommodate the calories, had the odd scotch or manhattan, bottle of wine. My fruit/veg count is averaging 7 or 8 per day and I have more energy than I've had in years.
I am 65 years old. If I believed in what I read, this diet would not work. It does and I have only felt hungry on rare occasion. My wife is on the same diet with 1,000 calories per day. She has lost 17 pounds.

Comment: People are quick to blame these deaths on reckless speeding.  What evidence is there that they were recklessly speeding?  Look at the crash wreckage of the Kia,  the driver's side door frame remains in its original outline, the front wheel axle with brake rotor showing it retained it spacing from its wheel well and the passenger compartment.  Yes looks like the engine was somewhat pushed in to the passenger compartment but that might be a weakness of the Kia design & materials to allow such penetration, even at lower speeds.  Compare previous pictures of truly high speed crashes & the end result looks like the car was compressed into an unrecognizable solid body or ripped apart.  Those extremely large pillars & installing a curb that close to a highway is NOT standard practice in the US or most 1st world countries for good reason.  Unfortunately there will be more of these type of accidents/deaths along Farrington highway & you cannot automatically blame it on reckless speeding.

Comment: I don't know, if mourning, is the proper word. The vast majority of us never knew her at all. She was someone we saw video of, or read about...to this day most of us don't really know how much of what we read about her was true, and how much had some sort of bias. As a person that we could have ever met, or even caught a live glimpse of, that wasn't even an opportunity. I think it really is difficult to mourn someone you never actually knew. We mourn what we think in our heads about her most of which is likely fiction. Our memories are tinged by the time and place of their making, and hindsight. Those who can truly mourn are friends, and family and those who actually knew her or where influenced by something she did. For the rest of us, we aren't mourning a reality, just imaginings of who we thought or wanted her to be.Diana was turned into a tabloid story that made $$$ for media. Better to remember in quiet, than to enrich the wallets of those who care only for another $$ opportunity.

Comment: I'm no fan of Trudeau, but at last his handlers have told him to say the right thing,  "It is a fundamental responsibility of the prime minister to see that Canada's resources get to market."  He's got that part right.

The Kinder Morgan announcement is welcome, although long overdue.  Note that since commencing in 1956, there has never been a tanker spill from the Kinder Morgan operation.  Never.  And the new regimen requires more tugs to escort each tanker and that each tanker be escorted much farther than before; to the open ocean at Cape Flattery.

Something opponents like to overlook is that there are already over 1,100 transits by tanker in the Juan de Fuca Strait each year, the bulk of these carrying American oil from Alaska to refineries in Washington State.  To oppose this Kinder Morgan approval on the basis of increased tanker traffic is to believe American oil is good and Canadian oil is bad; or by extension American prosperity is good, Canadian prosperity is bad.

Comment: Here it is: the various JDF and JMSDF uniforms and weapons.

Japanese JMSDF have adopted the M4 Carbine, 5.56 mm, M4 which is considered a "special forces" weapon. US Marines are already considering moving on to a more advanced M27 Infantry Automatic Rifle but still use the M4.

The Japanese make some of their own weapons but often under license from US or European companies. They don't currently have a huge weapons industry like the US and Europeans.

The JMSDF pattern seen in the CB photo is most likely the Type III Flecktarn camouflage which is widely adopted by the Japanese military. They actually don't have separate services like the US. The JMSDF provides US Marine like support to the Japanese Navy which all comes under the JMSDF -  Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force.

Note: In the US the word Marine is always capitalized. They are NOT soldiers.

Comment: Part 1
In many cases, it is impossible to get legal status.  Family based-visas are limited to spouses, children, parents and siblings of US citizens and to spouses and unmarried children of permanent residents (green-card holders).  If someone does not have a qualifying relative, then this route is closed.  Nonimmigrant (ie temporary) visas are not available to those who are here without authorization.  Employment-based immigrant visas (those that permit adjustment of status to permanent resident) are  often difficult to obtain and expensive and require an employer who is willing to pay the costs (including attorney fees).  Getting such a visa petition approved does not permit one to remain here.  One must apply for and get permanent residence to remain.  If one is not in lawful status, one cannot apply for permanent residence in the US, but must leave the country to process abroad.  But if one has been present unlawfully for a year or more, one may not return for 10 years. 
Contd

Comment: Well, the Defence may know for certain that there is no (or little) chance of a prosecution succeeding, but some Crown Attorneys will take a weak case to trial out of some misguided sense of judicial vigilante-ism (some have said this publicly). The purpose of the preliminary inquiry in this case is, I gather, to get the suspect off the hook sooner rather than later.

The problem with taking weak cases to court is it bogs down the system, leading to the situation we have now. The problem, therefore, can be resolved to some degree by making Crown Attorneys responsible for their vindictive decisions. How? That is the interesting question.

If you think this is a trivialization of a serious situation, I will point out that for the crimes attributed to Paul Bernardo, there were some 2500 suspects, with some that could have gone to trial based on mostly circumstantial evidence.

Comment: Henry VIII actually had solid grounds for an annulment, Catherine of Aragon had originally been married to Henry's brother, Arthur, who died. One needs a dispensation to marry your brother's widow, and Henry's father had pressured the Archbishop of Canterbury into giving it. Thus, Henry had a justified claim that the dispensation was improperly given.

However, Catherine opposed the annulment, probably because she didn't want her daughter Mary to lose her place as Henry's heir. So she claimed that she  had never consummated her marriage to Arthur. She also got her nephew, Charles II, to oppose the annulment. Charles, who disliked Henry both personally and politically, was happy to oblige his aunt.

Among other things, Charles was King of Naples. Naples and the Papal States had recently had a war. The pope lost, and didn't want a rerun. So he pretended to take Catherine's claim seriously.

Henry forced his hand when he broke with Rome. That's why the annulment was denied.

FBI Director James Comey adjusts his tie before testifying to the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence hearing on “Russia’s intelligence activities" on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., January 10, 2017. 

The FBI has no evidence that Russia successfully hacked President-elect Donald Trump's campaign or the Republican National Committee (RNC), Federal Bureau of Investigation Director James Comey said on Tuesday.

Testifying before Congress for the first time since Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton on Nov. 8, Comey declined to answer a question about whether the FBI was investigating the possibility of links between Trump associates and Russia.

U.S. intelligence agencies on Friday released an assessment that Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered an effort to help Republican Trump's electoral chances by discrediting Clinton in the 2016 campaign

Comment: I love department stores. I remember the first time I went with my mother into Simpson's at Queen and Yonge in Toronto. It was exciting. Looking around at all the beautiful items for sale, I was amazed that we didn't have to pay to get in. When I started working, it was worth a trip to the 7th  floor to admire and dream over what was on display in Treasure House.

As for Sears, it's been good to me. Over the years, I got attractive, good quality children's clothes for half price or less at a nearby clearance centre. Currently, a local Sears store has had amazing sales and selection in women's clothing. I'll miss the Tradition and Jessica brands, but judging by the other shoppers you see at the mall, there certainly is a diversity of taste. In many ways, this is a weird and unpleasant time.

Comment: It's no more acceptable for invasive felines to destroy native amphibians (or insects) than it is for them to destroy birds.  Actually it can be argued that allowing your invasive vermin to torture and destroy amphibians is worse--amphibians are currently in more dire straits than birds.  They're far less numerous, far more susceptible to environmental perturbations, and are suffering species-level extinctions at a much greater rate.  Three common species I encountered in the field when I was younger, the mountain yellow-legged frog (Rana muscosa), the lowlands leopard frog (R. yavapaiensis) and the Yosemite toad (Bufo canorus) are critically endangered--they've disappeared from 99% for their former ranges, because of two invasive species: the American bullfrog (Rana catesbeiana) and a deadly invasive fungus it carries, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis.  And you want to unleash your noxious killer felines on them too?  What did frogs ever do to you?  Oh right--they're not cats.

It's amazing - ten-thousand years of creating technology to make work easier and have less of it to do - and never before have people had to work as much or as hard to survive as they do now. Comment: Great article! For very cheap practice that can be done almost anywhere, I recommend a decent quality air pistol like a Crosman 1322 or 1377. Handguns are difficult to shoot accurately. Just like the article said, it doesn't take much of a flinch or bad technique to ever so slightly pull the gun off target just by the action of squeezing the trigger. A pneumatic airgun doesn't recoil so you can really notice how you are pulling or pushing the gun. Another way is a laser training cartridge that allows you to use your firearm for training and helps out a lot to get the feel of the trigger. Its amazing how much goes into shoot accurately. 

Target shooting in general is very rewarding. If you do it right you can actually feel each heart beat and how it moves the crosshairs on a scoped rifle. I find it to be a relaxing hobby, kind of like mediation but with action and fun.

Comment: Although the UK ONS stopped publication of its RPIJ series with this February update, its inflation rate can still be calculated approximately from information provided in the CPI briefing note. Its annual inflation rate for February 2017 was 2.4%, up from 1.8% in January, which compares with a CPIH inflation rate of 2.3% for February, up from 1.9% in January. This RPIJ inflation rate is too low as the RPI/RPIJ does not include stamp duty, as it should; the experimental ONS consumer price series for stamp duty had an annual inflation rate of 3.0% for 1986Q4.) This would be the best measure of inflation for escalation purposes until such time as the UK starts publishing a household inflation index.

Comment: The argument that the "Big Island Has Too Much To Lose If TMT Leaves" is a hollow argument. When measured against the tremendous social, cultural, historical, spiritual and personal loss the desecration of mauna a wakea represents to Hawaiians the loss of a jobs, revenue and a telescope site pales in comparison.

A telescope can be moved to another mountaintop in another nation whose people have lost their connection to their culture and to their sacred places.   On a per capita basis Elkton must have more enthusiastic volunteers than any  other town in Oregon.  The event was capped off with its historic pageant which especially featured the finest bunch of kids that any town would be proud of.  For many visitors  who hadn't known of England's control of Oregon through its forts, this was an eye opener as long buried history came alive.  

If there was any imperfection to a grand event, it was that Ft. Umpqua's role as as  the British Hudsons Bay Company's  "Bastion of Empire" and fur collecting center was somewhat lost in the hubub of living history characters and purveyors of American souvenir trinkets.

Comment: About 30 years ago I gave evidence at an inquest into the death of Lester Donaldson, a mentally-ill man who was shot by police. The jury came out with the same recommendations that have been repeated by every jury since then, yet the deaths are still happening. What we are doing is simply not working. 
The one common factor with all of these deaths is that the person involved has either refused treatment or has stopped medication. As any relative of a person suffering from schizophrenia can tell you, people with a serious mental illness often have no insight into their illness and do not believe that they are ill. Yet they are allowed to make medical decisions on the false assumption that they are competent. 
A way must be found to treat people before they become so agitated and confused that they become violent. Unfortunately our society is so hung up on individual rights above all else that the mentally-ill are allowed to destroy themselves rather than submit to treatment.

Comment: Although I have never been on welfare, neither have I been wealthy. For most of my life, I have been reasonably healthy. I have a small service-connected disability, but it is only in the past couple of years that I have needed some serious medical care. Without the VA, I doubt I would have been able to afford the care I needed and therefore doubt I would be alive today. This is my 80th year and, believe me, the body is not what it once was. My VA medical care has been more than acceptable, even with trips to Roseburg and, in a couple of cases, Portland and Seattle. Eugene's new clinic is a major improvement over the old River Road one, with the addition of more services such as a lab.

The Trump administration contains many people who want to privatize many aspects of our lives and the VA is one of them. Of course, like all human endeavors, it is not perfect. However, adding millions of vets to the non-VA medical system would overwhelm the already overloaded medical services industry.

Comment: "Populism" is used many times during this article as a derogatory term but does the author know what it means?
Populism - the political doctrine that supports the rights and powers of the common people in their struggle with the privileged elite. (vocabulary.com)
Populism - a political doctrine that proposes that the common people are exploited by a privileged elite, and which seeks to resolve this. The underlying ideology of populists can be left, right, or center. (Wikipedia)
Both traditional parties were thrown out in the first vote, therefore the rise of both Le Pen and Macron are due to a surge in populist sentiment. Whether one is "bad" and one is "good" depends on your political point of view. You can argue from different political perspectives about what the public wants, but it is certainly not more of the same. The elites have been shown the door in France as clearly as in the USA and Britain. 
Populism will continue to grow until the concerns of the people are addressed.

Comment: You misunderstand the origin of the Second Amendment. The Framers did not put the Second Amendment into the Bill of Rights sot hat citizens could one day overthrow the government. That's what the opening clause means: "A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State..." Its purpose was to provide security TO the new nation, not FROM it. President Washington was the first to call up the militia under the Second Amendment, to put down the Whiskey Rebellion AGAINST the federal government's tax on whiskey.

Comment: "...shut it down and die."

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. Maybe replace it with global representatives from the 150 or so National Conferences of Bishops representing 1.2 billion Catholics? I don't know. I haven't the answer except that it will take a long time to dismantle the Curia -- to make the unrigging successful. Bishops can do it by asserting themselves as individual national bodies, but that seems unlikely right now. Some National Conferences of Bishops, of course, are more progressive than others. In the meantime, in dealing with abuse in churches (and everywhere, really), the best route (for bringing about reform) seems to be through local civil courts, sympathetic laypeople and clerics, the press, and Pope Francis. If courts jailed a few bishops, that might help a lot, too.

Comment: I find it rather telling that the this story has drifted off the front pages of virtually all the mainstream media.

This story SHOULD be front-page news.  This is our government using accounting practices that would be straight-up illegal if it were a private sector company and is only legal because the government can pass a law saying it is legal for them to do so.

This is our government booking the present value of estimated future income as an asset today, all in order to "offset" debt and make current spending appear as if it were revenue, not spending .  If that sounds familiar it is because that is PRECISELY what Enron did in the late 1990's.  Their CEO was convicted of fraud for this and sentenced to 24 years in jail for doing so.

This is NOT a story that should be swept under the rug.

Comment: This "crap" is at the very foundation of the civil rights movement. Do you not recall the lunch counter sit-ins? Should businesses be allowed to discriminate based on anything they wish? That would invariably lead to economic isolation of marginalized groups in a big way.

When one enters the realm of business, one has to set aside many beliefs and play by the rules. Those rules are in place so that one group can't legally create an unfair advantage or disadvantage for various groups. No one is forcing this woman to provide her service, but if she chooses to do it for money, then she can't discriminate any more than the owner of an apartment complex can.

By the way, fighting for civil rights does indeed have consequences at the ballot box. LBJ was alleged to have said when he signed the Civil Rights Act that the Democrats had just lost the South for a generation. He was overly optimistic. The GOP still controls the South on just these issues over fifty years later.

Comment: Watercraft - boat, PWC, surfboard whatever - that are contrasting colors to the ocean are much easier to see.  I was aboard a Coast Guard Cutter a number of years ago; we were conducting a search pattern for a missing motorized kayak and were practically on top of it before we could see it.  It was dark blue.  I can't over-emphasize the need to file a float plan; leave it with a responsible friend or relative so if something happens it'll be a lot easier for responders to search for and find you.  I'm in the Coast Guard Auxiliary; local flotillas can provide much more information.

Comment: Richard Corbeil wrote: "Sales tax is not regressive. Spend $10, pay 30 cents. Spend $100, pay $3. Spend 1000, pay $30. That is by definition progressive. "  

Perhaps it's progressive in your mind RC because you are buying more expensive stuff in your example :)  Here's one definition I found:

"In terms of individual income and wealth, a regressive tax imposes a greater burden (relative to resources) on the poor than on the rich: there is an inverse relationship between the tax rate and the taxpayer's ability to pay, as measured by assets, consumption, or income. These taxes tend to reduce the tax burden of the people with a higher ability to pay, as they shift the relative burden increasingly to those with a lower ability to pay."

(a) The militia of the United States consists of all able-bodied males at least 17 years of age and, except as provided in section 313 of title 32, under 45 years of age who are, or who have made a declaration of intention to become, citizens of the United States and of female citizens of the United States who are members of the National Guard.

(1) the organized militia, which consists of the National Guard and the Naval Militia; and

Comment: Let's review the logic of Obamacare. In order to cover pre-existing conditions, you have to both have a mandate and subsidies, otherwise only the very ill/diseased will sign up and premiums will be too high for almost everyone. So, community rating means getting the bulk of the community in the pool.

In order to pay for the necessary subsidies, there had to be increased taxes on the very wealthy. Most people with an ounce of compassion find a small increase in taxes on millionaires and billionaires to be worthwhile in the cause of providing health insurance, and thus health care, to nearly all Americans.

Comment: Again, nothing but empty words from Johnson supporters.  Here are some more of those inconvenient facts:

1.  The Biological Opinion for the Prowler to Growler transition says that 92 db is the disturbance level for marbled murrelets.
2.  Exhibit J to the 2014 Navy Northwest Testing and Training EIS says the Electronic Warfare Range will result in 105 db sound levels in the marbled murrelet critical habitat. And this figure is a statistical average that understates the true impact.
3.  105 db is over 100 times louder than 92 db.  If 92 db is the disturbance level (which is damage) then 105 exceeds that and damages marbled murrelet habitat.

Name-calling such as "anti-militarism and anti-science" do not advance the discussion. Maybe in the end, people don't care about wildlife, or wilderness, or transparency and open public process, but let's at least get serious about what the issues are and discuss our shared future in an intelligent way.

Comment: There are some research that seems kind of sketchy to support your point, but research particular to Hawaii says otherwise.  The avian population of Hawaii is rapidly disappearing, largely because of a type of malaria that infects birds.  Before whalers brought mosquitoes in the early 19th century, birds in the Hawaiian Islands had no exposure to the diseases that mosquitoes carry, and therefore no immunity.  Now only 42 of more than a hundred species endemic to Hawaii remain, and three quarters of those are listed as endangered.  The American Bird Conservancy has referred to Hawaii as the "bird extinction capital of the world". Avian malaria is destroying the bird population, while environazis obsess about cats.
